ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: think from different perspectives; discuss and build upon thoughts and concepts

I gained the abilities to analyze a series of images to draw conclusions, to think visually, to think holistically about the city and its development, and to research the context of an image. I improved my abilities to articulate thoughts in a discussion and to apply readings to conversation.

I think this course helped my ability to analyze visual media tremendously. It also provided me with some basic ideas about the impressions varying architectural and urban planning styles are attempting to impart that I now carry with me in the spaces I navigate.
An understanding of architectural history/theory, knowledge about a wide array of modern cities, and a greater appreciation for the built environment around me.

I have genuinely been swayed to pursue a degree in architecture because of this course. All concepts presented represented intersections of diverse fields of thought. I better understand the general vocabulary used to describe ideas of spatial justice and the pursuit of a true public realm in an architectural sense. All collage and written work done in this course bolstered my appreciation of the material presented as well.
How to speed read and scan more efficiently to cover all the readings. How to think more broadly and approach the question from many different angles.
It Introduced me to many base ideas and figures in international architecture. Giving a really good introduction to architectural thought.

I learned to apply readings to a broader scale that encapsulates many forms of media. I also learned to think critically about architecture and how our world is influenced by different architectural practices.
by engaging with the material in class discussions, I developed my close analysis skills

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The format of this course was helpful to challenging my stream of reasoning rather than challenging my notetaking ability. The use of images in this class required me to engage with images and their ideas. Sitting at a table with our professor made me feel comfortable contributing in discussion. I loved the open discussion and development of ideas that was directed by the professor but fueled by class comments. The conversation was open to all students.

I think Professor Schlabs' immense knowledge and engaging teaching style was a huge strength of the course. I also took a lot away from my peers' perspectives and ideas. The readings were often also very well selected and I enjoyed seeing them fit into the class discussion.

The biggest strength of the course was the professor! Surry was incredibly engaging, insightful, and encouraging, and even though I had absolutely no knowledge of architecture prior to this class/had never traveled to any of the cities we were studying, I never felt afraid to make observations and comments in class. The readings, although they were a bit dense/jargon-filled at times, were absolutely fascinating (I especially enjoyed the Abidjan, Commons, and New Haven units). Occasionally, I wished there was a bit more connection between readings and seminar (class sessions mainly focused on visual aspects of cities/art) and the collage/art assignments were quite tricky to execute well as someone who hasn't had much art experience in the past. Overall, though, this was a super cool humanities credit and a wonderful start to my 4 years at Yale!

The readings were always directly relevant to seminar discussions. Professor Schlabs always curated his discussions to a point where all subject material was covered, but there was still ample opportunity for abstraction from the group. This allowed for an enriching experience in understanding how different personal backgrounds affect interpretation of the built environment.

Some strengths of the course were that almost every reading was absolutely fascinating to read (though some were very long) and the collage assignments were very enjoyable to do and allowed for a lot of creativity and freedom. Professor Schlabs has so much knowledge and runs a very fun, interesting discussion based class that covers so many topics like architecture, politics, protest, art and more. No weaknesses.
I absolutely loved this course and the way it was run.
I really enjoyed the approach and the way of thinking this course offered

strengths: presented a very different way of thinking, topics were very interesting
weaknesses: content was sometimes all over the place, didn't follow a linear pattern
this was my favorite course and the way it was taught could not be improved

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes - it's a great insight into architecture and urban studies while also focusing on various social injustices; there is a lot of reading, and the material can be very dense, but the discussions are based on your interpretations of the reading and not just on the reading itself

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. This course helped me question space and accessibility in cities. As a person, encountering the city is inevitable, and becoming conscious of privilege and problems in the city is important for all students, not just those interested in Architecture or Urban Studies.

I would definitely recommend this course to fellow students as I think the professors way of guiding the classes analyses was deeply helpful and improves analytical skills across disciplines. In addition, I think the student would enjoy the content regardless of a specific interest in architecture or urbanism.

Yes, if you feel confident discussing art and architecture in a seminar setting! This class was full of interesting, new experiences (presenting my artistic work in the architecture building, reading urban studies documents in the Sterling manuscripts room, analyzing modern art), and I always looked forward to attending class and hearing the fascinating insights and opinions of my classmates!
Yes, this course was amazing. I recommend it to anyone that is at all interested in the subject matter.
I would certainly recommend this course to others. Was much better than I assumed it would be. Great for any student considering architecture or any student with a love for art
Yes, I would

This is an amazing, comprehensive course that is super interesting and covers a lot of cool material in a manageable way while also leaving room to foster your particular interest! I absolutely loved the course and it builds an amazing foundation for other courses but it's definitely interesting enough to take just as a standalone/introduction class. Just take it!
Yes! this was my favorite course.
